intro: Silene zawadskii, commonly known as the Zawadski's campion, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of the Eastern Carpathians in Poland. It is a member of the Caryophyllaceae family, characterized by its showy, pinkish-red flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine soils, thriving in cool, moist environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and often branched. Silene zawadskii is a rare and endangered species, making it a subject of conservation interest due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity.
